previous_statement: EVALUATION AT ROOTS OF p AND SIGN ALTERNATION. Evaluate f at the roots lambda_1 < ... < lambda_n of p: f(lambda_i) = p'(lambda_i) - nc p(lambda_i) = p'(lambda_i), since p(lambda_i) = 0. Now p'(lambda_i) = prod_{j != i} (lambda_i - lambda_j) is real and nonzero. The sign of p'(lambda_i) is (-1)^{n-i}: for i = n (largest root), all factors (lambda_n - lambda_j) with j < n are positive, giving p'(lambda_n) > 0; for i = n-1, we get one negative factor and (n-2) positive ones (from j < n-1), giving p'(lambda_{n-1}) < 0; in general the sign is (-1)^{n-i}. Crucially: f(lambda_i) is REAL for each i, and consecutive values f(lambda_i), f(lambda_{i+1}) have OPPOSITE signs (since (-1)^{n-i} and (-1)^{n-i-1} differ in sign). Note: although f has complex coefficients (since c in C^-), the values f(lambda_i) are real because the imaginary parts cancel: Im(f(lambda_i)) = Im(p'(lambda_i)) - Im(nc) Re(p(lambda_i)) - Re(nc) Im(p(lambda_i)) = 0 - Im(nc) * 0 - Re(nc) * 0 = 0, using p(lambda_i) = 0 and p'(lambda_i) real.
new_statement: EVALUATION AT ROOTS OF p. Evaluate f at the roots lambda_1 < ... < lambda_n of p: f(lambda_i) = p'(lambda_i) - nc p(lambda_i) = p'(lambda_i), since p(lambda_i) = 0. Now p'(lambda_i) = prod_{j \!= i} (lambda_i - lambda_j) is real and nonzero (since all roots are simple and real). In particular, f(lambda_i) \!= 0 for all i. This confirms that the roots of p are NOT roots of f, so the n roots of f are in bijection with the n solutions of G_p(w) = c. Additionally, f(lambda_i) is REAL for each i: although f has complex coefficients (since c in C^-), the imaginary part vanishes at each lambda_i because Im(f(lambda_i)) = Im(p'(lambda_i)) - Im(nc) * p(lambda_i) = 0 - 0 = 0 (using p(lambda_i) = 0 and p'(lambda_i) real).
